name: Import
description: A purist who lives and breathes Japanese tuner culture

main.title: The Spirit of JDM
main.description: Prove you understand and respect the culture

chapters.title: Culture Test
chapters.summary: Import evaluates whether you understand the culture or just the cars

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: So Muscle sent you.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: He's good people. Old school. Different world from mine, but we respect each other.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: But respect doesn't transfer. You have to earn your own.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Tell me - what does JDM mean to you?

choices.text: It's more than cars. It's a philosophy. Function over form. Building with purpose.
Japanese Domestic Market. Cars and parts designed for Japanese roads and regulations.
Fast Japanese cars. Skylines, Supras, that stuff.

basic_response.speaker: import
basic_response.text: That's what everyone says. The Instagram kids with their fake carbon.

basic_response.speaker: import
basic_response.text: JDM is about building something that speaks to you. Not following trends.

basic_response.speaker: import
basic_response.text: Come back when you understand that.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Finally. Someone who gets it.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Most people come here wanting a big wing and a loud exhaust. Clout.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: They don't care about balance. About how a car communicates through the wheel.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: What's your build? And don't tell me it's 'for the gram.'

choices.text: ETK-I 2400ti. I'm focused on suspension and handling. Power means nothing if you can't control it.
Working on a project car. Trying to find the balance between street and track.
Just building something I enjoy driving.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Suspension first. You really do understand.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: The Japanese call it 'shikkari' - a car that feels planted, connected.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: When the suspension is right, the car tells you what it can do. Before you even push it.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: That's the foundation of touge. Mountain driving. Reading the road.

choices.text: Touge is an art. It's not about lap times, it's about the dance between driver and machine.
I've watched a lot of Initial D. Always wanted to experience that feeling.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Let me ask you something.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: You see two builds. One has every expensive part, professionally installed. The other is budget, mismatched, but the owner did everything themselves.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Which one do you respect more?

choices.text: The owner-built one. The connection between builder and car matters more than the parts list.
Both have merit. Different paths to the same destination.
The professional build. Quality matters.

wrong_answer.speaker: import
wrong_answer.text: You can buy a perfect build. But you can't buy soul.

wrong_answer.speaker: import
wrong_answer.text: Every scratch, every imperfect weld, every late night in the garage - that's what makes a build real.

wrong_answer.speaker: import
wrong_answer.text: Think about that and come back.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: *smiles*

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: That's the right answer.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: In Japan, there's a concept called 'wabi-sabi.' Finding beauty in imperfection.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: A car with history, with battle scars, with stories... that's more beautiful than any showroom queen.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Alright. You've earned a chance.

choices.text: Thank you for giving me that chance.
I'm looking forward to learning more about the culture.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I have access to authentic parts. Body kits, suspension components, interior pieces.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: The real stuff. Not replicas.

chapters.title: The Scene
chapters.summary: Import introduces you to the local tuner scene

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: There's a meet this weekend.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Small. Private. The real heads only.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: No Instagram photographers. No drama. Just cars and conversation.

choices.text: I'd love to be there. That sounds like the real deal.
What kind of cars usually show up?

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: All kinds. A guy with a restored Ibishu Pessima wagon. Another with a right-hand-drive Covet.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: There's this woman who built a Sunburst from scratch. Track-prepped. Twelve years in the making.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: The diversity is what makes it special. United by passion, not by brand.

choices.text: That's the community I want to be part of.
Twelve years on one build... that's dedication.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: You know how I got into this?

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: My grandfather was a machinist in Japan. After the war, he worked at a small tuning shop in Yokohama.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: He told me stories about the early days. When people modified cars not for speed, but for survival.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Making do with what you had. Improvising. Creating.

choices.text: That heritage is important. It connects you to something bigger.
Is that why authenticity matters so much to you?

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Exactly.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Every fake part, every replica kit, every shortcut... it disrespects that history.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: My grandfather didn't have the option to buy cheap knockoffs. He had to make things work.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: That ingenuity, that craftsmanship... that's what I try to honor.

choices.text: I understand. It's about respecting the craft, not just consuming the product.
That's a beautiful philosophy.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I knew you'd understand.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Here - access to my better inventory. Authentic parts. Some rare pieces.

chapters.title: The Gathering
chapters.summary: Import invites you to an exclusive event

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I'm planning something.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: A gathering. Like the ones my grandfather talked about.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: No spectators. No social media. Just builders, and a mountain road.

choices.text: A modern touge event. Taking it back to the roots.
That sounds incredible. When?

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Exactly. No racing. No competition. Just... experiencing the drive.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I've scouted a route. Twisty, technical. The kind of road that rewards precision.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Sunrise start. Convoy style. Then breakfast at a caf√© at the summit.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I'm only inviting a few people. The ones who truly understand.

choices.text: I'm honored to be considered.
This is what the culture should be about.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: You're in.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: I've been watching your build. The choices you've made. The way you approach it.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: You're not chasing numbers or clout. You're building something you believe in.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: That's rare. That's what this community needs more of.

choices.text: I learned from watching people like you.
The culture saved me. This is how I give back.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Then let's keep it alive together.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Full access to my network. Anything you need, we'll find it.

exchanges.speaker: import
exchanges.text: Welcome to the family.

confrontations.text: Someone offered to sell me a 'JDM' hood with perfect English stickers. Said it was 'imported from Japan.' What do you think?

responses.text: Fake. Real JDM parts have Japanese text. Someone's trying to scam you.
Might be legit? Some parts do get English labels for export.
I'd need to see it in person to judge.

unknown.text: What draws you to Japanese car culture?

responses.text: The philosophy. Function over form. Continuous improvement.
The cars. They're well-engineered and fun to drive.
